origination.corpname: University of Michigan. School of Dentistry.

did.unittitle: School of Dentistry (University of Michigan) records
did.abstract: The School of Dentistry is a teaching and research unit of the University of Michigan. Records include administrative files, faculty meeting minutes, curriculum and education, subject files relating to dentistry and to the professional interests of the school's faculty; and photographs and films.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Material was first received from the School of Dentistry in 1939 (donor no. 764). The bulk of the records were received in 1984. Faculty minute volumes were received in 2001.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The Dental School record group is open in part, boxes 12-34 are subject to the Executive Offices restriction. The Dental School record group includes restricted material in the following categories:

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, School of Dentistry (University of Michigan), Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The College of Dental Surgery at the University of Michigan was founded by the Regents in 1875. The practicing dentists of the state were instrumental in its creation. They had originally petitioned the Regents in 1866 for the establishment of a chair of dentistry. When that petition failed to win regental approval, dentists submitted another petition in 1873. The Regents expressed a willingness to approve this second request, but claimed lack of funds made action impossible. The dentists then turned to the state legislature where they were successful in obtaining a special appropriation for the purpose of teaching dentistry at the university.

Originally dentistry was taught by two professors. They, and those subsequently appointed to the faculty, developed a college noted for the adeptness of its graduates in technical and operative areas. Throughout the nineteenth century the college's focus was primarily on technique, but at the beginning of the twentieth century research began to assume an important position in the college's activities. The first major project was undertaken by Marcus Ward, who in 1903 began a study of the properties of dental amalgams used as filling material. Research was also carried on in areas of surgical procedures, with particular success in the area of restoration. Eventually, research became a common activity among the faculty.

Throughout the twentieth century the nature of the student body and the character of the subjects taught developed and changed. In 1921 dental hygiene was first taught, largely to women who would go on to become dental assistants and technicians. By 1927, when the college was renamed the School of Dentistry, the need for both continuing education for practicing dentists and for post-graduate educational opportunities for students had been recognized and was being acted upon. The W. K. Kellogg foundation was particularly instrumental during the 1930s and 1940s in making funds and space available for these two activities.

Space was a continuing problem for the school. When it was founded, the school was placed in a university-owned house, originally used as a faculty residence. In 1877 the school was relocate into a larger building, another university-owned house originally used by a faculty member. In 1891 the school inherited the old university Hospital. During 1908 and 1909 a special building was erected for the Dental School, on North University Avenue. This building was enlarged in 1923. In 1939-1940, with funds supplied by the W. K. Kellogg Foundation and the Works Progress Administration, the W. K. Kellogg Foundation Institute: Graduate and Postgraduate Dentistry Building was constructed. In 1969, as part of a major construction program initiated the year before, the 1908 structure was razed. It was replaced by a complex of buildings completed in 1971.

chronlist.head: Deans of the School of Dentistry

scopecontent.p: The School of Dentistry record group spans the years from 1873 to 2010, but does not comprehensively document the entire span. The records are fragmentary, providing only a partial picture of the School of Dentistry. Documentation reflects the tenures of various deans with scattered documents from the late 1800s and more detail in the period 1920-1990. The records give some insight into the development of dentistry as a profession, and the training and education of dental students. The records, comprised of 33.5 linear feet, have been divided into nine series: Educational Information, Administration, Organizations, Surveys, Photographs and Audiovisual Materials, Department Chairpersons' Meetings, Faculty Meetings, American Dental Association Accreditation, Dental Research Institute, and Website

scopecontent.p: The series Educational Information brings together information about the history of the school, its educational programs and curriculum, departments within the school, work with students, and some student notebooks and related material collected by the school over the years. Also included are some interesting publications and speeches by dentistry professors from other universities. Information on departments within the School of Dentistry reflects the structure of the school and activities of the departments from the 1960s through the 1980s.

An outsize ledger volume of unknown provenance that was donated to the School of Dentistry, details the dental practice of Dr. James [likely in Kalamazoo, Michigan]. The volume contains patient records from this practice dating from 1873 to 1895.

The Educational Information series is comprised of two chronologically defined subseries, 1875-1989 and ca. 1956- 1997, reflecting different accessions. The 1956- 1997 subseries is restricted under Executive Offices rule.

scopecontent.p: The series Administration (1899-1999, 14.3 linear feet) includes administrative information on topics such as admissions, interaction with other university units, committees, evaluations of faculty and administration, reports, and finances during the period from 1899 to 1999. In addition, this series contains records from eight deans of the School of Dentistry: Russell W. Bunting, Paul H. Jeserich, William R. Mann, Marcus L. Ward, Robert E. Doerr, Richard L. Christiansen, William Kotowicz, and J. Bernard Machen. The Dean's files are comprised mainly of correspondence, although some speeches and publications and a small amount of biographical information will also be found here. Other material in this series includes background on the W. K. Kellogg Foundation Institute, and information on dental activities in Latin America covering 1944-1974.

scopecontent.p: The Faculty Meetings series (1899-1994, 2 linear feet) document administrative issues central to the School of Dentistry. Issues covered include curriculum, finances, tenure and promotion, and clinical services. The volumes (1899-1979) of faculty meeting minutes offer the most comprehensive picture of dental education at the University of Michigan. The folders (1967-1994) contain agendas and minutes that document discussions about significant issues. The material from the 1980s and 1990s focuses mostly on budget and financial issues, clinical services, and the status of lecturers and instructors. Other topics include the development of new graduate programs, department reports and updates, discussion and approval of various policies and procedures, bylaw revisions, introductions of new faculty members, and results of votes for committee appointments.

The Organizations series (1901-1981, 0.8 linear feet) is arranged alphabetically and contains information about students organizations (social and professional), and dentistry organizations both internal and external to the university.

did.unittitle: Minutes of the Board of Governors
National Dental Examinations: University of Michigan Results
School of Dentistry Reports to ADA
Dental Faculties Association of American Universities

scopecontent.p: The series Surveys (1936-1961, 1.3 linear feet) contains different studies and questionnaires evaluating dental education and curriculum. This series also includes a major survey done by the School of Dentistry in 1960 studying dentistry programs in the United States. Questionnaires, tabulations, evaluations and correspondence between deans and professors from other dental schools and the University of Michigan School of Dentistry are part of the files.

did.unittitle: Survey of Curriculums of US Dental Schools
Survey of Dental Hygiene Programs in the United States
Survey of Dental Schools in the United States, undated
Questionnaire for Deans of Dental Schools

scopecontent.p: The Photographs and Audiovisual Materials (0.8 linear feet) series contains miscellaneous prints and scattered negatives of School of Dentistry students, professors, and interior and exterior views of the school. It also contains a set of audio recordings "Dental Series" in 45 rpm on one side, and 33 1/3 rpm on the other side, which discuss care of teeth. In addition, there are three motion picture films in 16 mm format.

scopecontent.p: The Department Chairpersons' Meetings series (1982-1998, 1.5 linear feet) contains agendas, related documents, and meeting minutes of the Dean's meetings with department chairpersons from 1982 to 1998. Materials document discussions of various major topics in the administration of the School of Dentistry. Topics of discussion include: tenure and promotion, budget and financial sustainability issues, curriculum, enrollment, fundraising and development efforts, current research, research priorities, and maintenance and access to research facilities.

The American Dental Association Accreditation series (1942-2002, 1.5 linear feet) documents the School of Dentistry's participation in the American Dental Association (ADA) accreditation process. The series is divided into two subseries: General (1942-2002) and Specialties (1978-1987). The General subseries contains correspondence, self-evaluations, and final reports from the 1970s and 1980s, an internal review from 2002, and a survey of dental schools from 1942-1943. The Specialties subseries includes progress reports and accreditation manuals for the Dental Hygiene, Endodontics, Orthodontics, and Prosthodontics programs within the School of Dentistry.

The Website series documents the academic programs, accomplishments, resources, events, and people at the School of Dentistry. Content includes important news and announcements, publications (such as newsletters and course catalogs), and information about admissions, curriculum, degree requirements, faculty, and the overall mission of the School. The website series is arranged chronologically and includes content captured by the Internet Archive starting in 1996 as well as captures provided by Bentley Library archivists in 2002, 2003, and 2008. Starting in 2010, this archived website will be captured on a regular, ongoing basis as part of the University of Michigan Web Archives, hosted at http://webarchives.cdlib.org/a/universityofmichigan/.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Miscellaneous material from the dental fraternity Delta Sigma Delta, including artifacts and photographs, are located in the Delta Sigma Delta Room at the Bentley Historical Library.
